Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is the analysis of mathematical mechanisms that explain how small actions exerted on dynamical systems can lead to large effects, and applications of these mechanisms to real-world systems, such as in astrodynamics, molecular biology and bioengineering, and climate science. In astrodynamics, small forces resulting from the intertwining of the natural gravity of Moon, Sun, and planets, can be exploited to design spacecraft trajectories to distant locations within the Solar System, or to correct the orbits of artificial satellites near the Earth, with significant fuel savings. In climate science, small changes in the system parameters, such as in the concentration of greenhouse gases, can cause sharp transitions of the climate from one regime to another, and the mathematical analysis of climate data can detect early warning signs of such transitions. In molecular biology, small changes in the structure of molecules involved in the process of protein folding can have significant functional effects; such changes can be detected via topological data analysis of electron microscopy imaging.

This project seeks to discover explicit mechanisms that produce large effects in general mathematical models of various real-world systems, as well as to infer such mechanisms directly from data. Data is often used in the case of complex systems where explicit models are difficult to conceive from fundamental principles. The first research direction is devoted to large effects in mechanical Hamiltonian systems subject to small perturbations, deterministic or random. The goal is to describe mechanisms that yield trajectories that travel a large distance in the phase space, as well as trajectories with prescribed itineraries. Applications of these mechanisms include astrodynamics and celestial mechanics. The second research direction is devoted to critical transitions in complex systems. The goal is to develop methods based on persistent homology that detect critical transitions in noisy dynamical systems with slowly evolving parameters, and to study topological changes in macromolecular processes. These methods are applied to paleoclimate data and GroEL/ES chaperonin systems involved in protein folding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was concerned with large effects in physical systems which are caused by small perturbations. For example, by applying  small rocket thrusts at appropriate times, one can obtain spacecraft trajectories that travel from the Earth to the Moon or other planets with very little energy cost. In such cases, one is interested in determining optimal ways to apply these thrusts.  A very different example is the financial markets, when small fluctuations of the asset prices can sometimes cause the markets to crash. In such cases, one is interested in detecting tipping  points of the market activity, when there is an increased risk of a crash.

In this project, these phenomena have been studied in several mathematical settings. A very general setting is that of Hamiltonian dynamics, which concerns mechanical systems whose total energy is preserved over time. A conjecture due to V.I. Arnold in 1964 claims that when small, periodic  perturbations  of general type are added to such systems, they yield trajectories along which the energy grows significantly. This project has applied a geometric method to to this problem, and provided solutions  in several general situations. Two major cases of the Arnold diffusion conjecture, the so called `a priori unstable' case, and `a priori stable' case, have been treated, and new mathematical methods were developed to solve these problems.  In addition, Arnold's conjecture was investigated  in a model describing the motion of a spacecraft relative to the Sun-Jupiter system. In this context, one can determine ways to exploit  the interspersing gravitational fields of Sun and Jupiter in order to produce large changes in the trajectory of the spacecraft.


For certain complex systems, it is difficult to conceive accurate mathematical models, and one has to rely on data analysis to obtain information on the evolution of the system. Part of the research in this project was devoted to developing tools, based on computational topology, which enable one to detect, directly from the data, the points in time when the system is near a critical transition, that is, when the system jumps from one state to a dramatically different state. The novel methodologies has been tested primarily on financial market crashes, however they are general enough to be applied to other  systems, such as from climate science and molecular biology.

The intellectual merits of this research consist in advancing the knowledge of general mechanisms through which small perturbations can lead to large effects, and in developing tools to apply these mechanisms to concrete systems.

The broader impacts of this work  stem primarily from the integration of research and education,  and through the involvement of undergraduate, master and doctoral students in research projects.This research program has contributed directly to the consolidation and growth of the recently reopened PhD program at Yeshiva University (YU), as well as to a heightened valuation of research by the university administration.The research activities of the PI also led to an increased participation of women in STEM areas. The PI is in a unique position to support women in STEM, as YU is has a women-only college embedded ina research university, and a women-only associated high school. In addition, this research program led to educational impacts in West Africa, through the organization of a  CIMPA-BENIN SCHOOL 2018 on ``Dynamical Systems and Applications: Geometrical, Topological and Numerical Aspects" at thehe African Center of Excellence in Mathematical Sciences and Applications (ACE-SMA) of the Institute of Mathematics and Physics, Benin. There is an ongoing collaboration between the PI and the ACE-SMA, with one of the aims being to open a masters program in dynamical systems at ACE-SMA and to organize joint educational activities.
